snippet.textDisplay:
WHY THE VIRUS IS SPREADING SO FAST?
We know that the virus is spread by people that are infected via their respiratory droplets. These droplets can land around themselves if they cough or sneeze, or to people around them nearby. The virus can stick to their hands if they touch the fluids in their noses or mouth. The virus can land on surfaces if the infected touch those surfaces. The virus can stay active on stainless steel surfaces for about 48 hrs or longer, and on paper and clothing for about 24 hrs.



To minimize that spread we have told the infected to put a mask so the viruses in their respiratory droplets are trapped on the mask and don’t fly out far from themselves. This is mask containment of the virus. We have told people to maintain social distance of 3 feet or about 1 meter so when the infected talks and breathes without a mask, his/her breath droplets don’t reach the others around them, yet the virus continue to spread very fast, the number of new cases keep on doubling almost every 3 days.



So, one question come to mind “Is the virus spreading in another way that we have not yet considering? And the answer is YES. The virus is spreading through the air and at distances more than 3 feet, perhaps as far as 15-30 feet or longer, especially by the infected that are not wearing masks.



Let me explain, if the virus remains active on surfaces for as long as 48 hours, then the virus will stay active for as long as it is protected and cocooned in the respiratory droplet that came out of the infected. When we exhale respiratory droplets near a glass we fog the glass. In winter we can make fog when we breathe. When we drive in fog one thing you notice is that fog doesn’t fall to the ground, it stays floating in the air. Similarly, exhale air droplets stays in the air for long time. The smaller the droplets the buoyant they are, they float. If there is airflow or wind, the droplets can travel a long way. We don’t know well the electrical polarity of the virus, but it could be that the viruses packed inside a water droplet are holding the droplet through surface tension and their polarity until that droplet touches a surface, breaking and unloading the viruses, like tiny Trojan horses.



Because these droplets are persistent in the air, people walking by will breathe in these infected droplets; some of them will land on their faces, mouth, eyes, ears, contributing to a larger spread of covid19.



Let me put things in perspective. The radius of a corona virus, from electron microscope graphs, is of the order of 0.0000375 mm, the radius of a pin head is about 0.75 mm. You can pack a layer of 397 million corona viruses on a pinhead. Now an exhaled droplet has a radius in the order of 5 micrometers or 0.005 mm, which is about the size of a fog droplet. In this droplet, that floats and persist in the air, that moves around to distances longer that 1 meter by airflow or wind, can carry as much as 2.3 million corona viruses. Therefore, the virus is hitching rides to large distances by airflow and wind, spreading itself to many more people.



I propose a simple experiment for the NIH and the WHO to perform immediately, and it is as follows: place an infected person to read a book out loud at the center of a 30 feet (10 m) wide room for 30 minutes. Place some fans to create airflow and simulate wind near the person, this will carry his/her droplets around the room. After 30 minutes take samples swabs on the walls, floor, and ceiling and test for the virus. I am 100% sure the virus will be found on all surfaces. If healthy people stands there, they would breathe in virus particles, getting infected.



How can we prevent the spread of the virus if it is persistent in the air? Everybody mask up, 100% of the population must wear a mask, handkerchief, scarf, whatever. The point is we need to hold the droplets on the mask. We all have to act as if we are all infected. Eventually we all are going to get infected, but this mandatory action will reduce the number of infected right away. The infection will continue to spread, but it will be gradual. Our hospitals will be able to handle the sick, and many lives will be saved.



I was a Nuclear Medical Science Officer with the US Army Public Health Command and I did studies on the health effects of airborne depleted uranium particulates. I have sent this analysis to the Public Health Command, the NIH and the WHO. The use of masks must be obligatory for all citizens.



MAJ (R) Angel Castellanos, Ph.D

Public Health Command, US Army.

Posted in Mass Media.

April 1, 2020.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've helped hundreds of patients and their families go through the dying process. Usually at the end of life it's pneumonia that comes along from being bed bound.
A lot of families may be facing whether to have their loved one die on a gurney and a hallway or at home.
Hospice services should be available locally and are provided in the home about 90% of the time.
I would say about 95% of families who elect palliative care would rather have the comfort of home with good care rather than all the hysteria of an emergency room / field Hospital.

..

I love how Governor Cuomo talks so slow, as if he's telling a nursery rhyme to America. "You have to pay attention! This is not puppy dogs and snowflakes"

..


"The system is about to collapse?"
You mean the for-profit system we have in our big beautiful capitalistic country, where everything is based on supply and demand versus government for the people, for the good of the people. Where we plan ahead, We pay out taxpayer dollar for the public good for the long run.
For example, over building Hospitals for an influx of patients and having extra supplies on hand.
On a different note, providing free or extremely low cost college education to our young people so that our country can benefit from it in the long run.
But no! We are a capitalistic society where everything's based on profit and money-making. So let's saddle those young people with lots of debt so that all the people who invest in those banks can make money off those kids.
Planning ahead, what!

..

Medical staff have to treat this as an assembly line of cars that need to be repaired. You cannot get enmeshed with these patients.
You have to keep your distance emotionally. Be competent, be polite, but do your job and move on to the next patient.
By far most patients and families do not want you crying and falling apart but rather being strong for them in this time of crisis.
Oh yes, there maybe the few that want you to hold her hand, pray and whatever else emotional crap, but that does no good for you or the next patient.
Otherwise you will burn out, which means he won't finish your career and you will not be effective in this crisis.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dr.Birx and others explain here @ how other cities are very different from NY because the other cities and states acted sooner. New York officials got thousands of citizens killed bc instead of treating it as a public health issue, like everyone else did, NY engaged in politically correct activism. No one else waited as long as NY to act. In fact they encouraged social gatherings while other states were banning them.
1/21 - First case of Coronavirus in the U.S.
1/31 - Trump bans travel from China. Liberals call it racist.
2/2 - NYC Health Commissioner: "The risk to New Yorkers from coronavirus is low and our preparedness as a city is very high. There's no reason not to go out and take the Subway, not to miss the parade(in Chinatown)."
2/22 - First death in Italy with cases skyrocketing
2/29 - First death in the U.S. with some cases
3/1 - Trump restricts travel from Italy. Many cities and states begin to encourage and even mandate smaller social gatherings. NY does the exact opposite in the name of social justice.
3/1 - NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio: "I'm encouraging New Yorkers to go on with your lives + get out on the town despite Coronavirus."
3/2 - Italy locks down the entire country as they are now overwhelmed
3/3 - More cities and states limit social gatherings.
3/10 - NY Gov.Cuomo: "This hysteria/fear/panic you see is unwarranted.”
3/11 - NBA cancels season
3/11 - NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio: "If you're not sick you should be going about your life."
3/20 - NY Gov.Cuomo switches from politics to governing: "This is not life as usual. Mandatory Stay-at-Home Order." Too little too late.
3/22 - NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio: "Trump isn't doing enough."

Throughout all of it Trump expressed hopeful sentiments. Now suddenly libs are against any sentiments of hope, or change. When Obama was trying to be positive and hopeful it was fine but when Trump does it it's lies = you're all hypocrites. Giving one side a total pass and crucifying the other side for the exact same thing is the kind of karma that is going to make you sick.

They all got caught goofing off and need someone to blame. The irony is if the President was Democrat they would have paid attention. The double irony is a Dem wouldn't have placed a travel ban until much later like NY waited until much later. Biden said so himself. Trump saved us from becoming Italy by a matter of days. NY is heading that way despite the rest of the country. One thing for sure that will change, these people won't be so quick to act like jackasses the next time Trump places a restriction on something.
